text.headline: "What a waste"
text.text: Life as a weirdo and the growth of bioinformatics

text.headline: The birth of bioinformatics
text.text: Dr. Margaret O. Dayhoff pioneers the use of computers to store and process protein sequences.  Dayhoff implements the first computer program to reconstruct a phylogenetic tree from molecular sequences, and a matrix scheme for comparing sequences that is the foundation to BLAST.  Dayhoff and Eck release the Atlas of Protein Sequence and Structure.

text.headline: Olga Kennard founds the CCDC
text.text: The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre is one of the earliest scientific databases and predecessor to the Protein Data Bank.

text.headline: Public release of NCBI Genbank
text.text: Building on Dayhoff's work, Walter Goad and the Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL) are awarded a grant to build a public database.  The initial release comprised about 2,000 sequence records.

text.headline: The UNISYS ICON
text.text: The Ontario Minister of Education Bette Stephenson advocates for microcomputers in the classroom.  The Canadian Educational Microprocessor Corporation wins the contract and creates the diskless ICON workstation.  This is my first exposure to a UNIX-like operating system and how I learn to code in C.

media.url: No, you're not going to end up working at a McDonald's if you go into evolutionary biology.

text.headline: First year biology in U Toronto
text.text: Convocation Hall is occupied by nearly 2,000 students.  We learn that evolution is a mixture of stochastic and deterministic processes.  I decide to become an evolutionary biologist.  My parents stage a series of interventions.

text.headline: Doing research out of peer pressure
text.text: Signs up for a 2nd year research opportunity because my friends are doing it.  Selects a population genetics lab because the words look neat.  Walks into the lab that afternoon and gets the job.  (Continues to walk into random labs.)

text.headline: Forays into weed ecology
text.text: Works as a summer research assistant at the Thornton Bales Conservation Area.  Inhaled fungicide.  Heatstroke.  Borrowed my mom's Volvo to transport samples - returned with trunk full of dirt and ants.

media.url: Some groups attempted to build large monolithic systems on top of complex relational databases; they were thwarted time and again by the highly dynamic nature of biological research.

text.headline: Perl saves the Human Genome Project
text.text: The Perl scripting language enables the interchange of data and results between centres participating in the Human Genome Project.  I don't hear about any of this until about 2003.

text.headline: High school teaching
text.text: Decided to become a high school teacher. Walked into University of Toronto Schools to volunteer and became responsible for Grade 11 Science. There is no training.  Became a goth and wore nail polish.

text.headline: Discovering math in biology
text.text: David Houle explains Kimura's diffusion approximation of genetic drift in 4th year population genetics. I get an NSERC.  David advises me to go train with Sally Otto.

text.headline: Racoons and UNIX
text.text: UBC Zoology is housed in WWII-era portables. I get the worst office and a pile of discarded NeXT workstations.  Hanging out with the IT staff yields an informal education in network IT and UNIX.  Also kayaks.

text.headline: First peer-reviewed paper
text.text: Revisits a model developed by RA Fisher in 1930.  Theoretical analysis of the chance that an endangered population may go extinct from the accumulation of harmful mutations.  (Spoiler: it's not likely.)   Learns about mathematical statistics, probability theory, stochastic processes and other cool things they don't teach in 2nd year stats.

text.headline: From the dry lab to the wet lab
text.text: Joins a bacteriophage experimental evolution lab to study compensatory evolution.  Argues constantly with supervisor.

media.credit: Excerpt from PEP 20 - The Zen of Python
media.url:
In the face of ambiguity, refuse the temptation to guess.
There should be one — and preferably only one — obvious way to do it.
Although that way may not be obvious at first unless you're Dutch.

text.headline: Python 2.0 is released
text.text: Like Perl, Python is a scripting language that adheres to a different philosophy.  It eventually supercedes Perl as the dominant language in bioinformatics.

text.headline: Computer intensive methods in statistics
text.text: Grad course taught at Scripps Institute of Oceanography by Jay Barlow. I couldn't afford MATLAB so I had to write my own programs in C. Every student received a stack of photocopied hand-written notes from Jay (I still have them).

text.headline: Compensatory mutation
text.text: Creates a new experimental system to measure the rate of compensatory mutation.  Collaborates with friend Brad Davis on meta-analysis of compensatory mutation rates using something called R.

text.headline: The X-Prize for the $1,000 genome is launched
text.text: The prize would later be cancelled in 2013 because sequencing technology improved faster than exponentially soon after the competition start date.
